title: Russia’s Swift March Forward in Ukraine’s East
body: In October, Russia made its largest territorial gains since the summer of 2022, as Ukrainian lines buckled under sustained pressure.

title: North Korea, in the Spotlight Over Ukraine, Launches a Long-Range Missile
body: North Korea launched an intercontinental ballistic missile off its east coast on Thursday, shortly after the United States and South Korea condemned the country for deploying troops near Ukraine to join Russia’s war effort.

title: How the U.S. Election Matters for the Rest of the World
body: Times foreign correspondents explain how the election’s outcome will impact various regions internationally. One thing is clear: This election polarizes the world as much as it does the United States — but sometimes in unexpected ways.

title: @nytimes
Moscow is employing a variety of tactics, including torture and forced Russian citizenship, to try to obliterate Ukrainian identity, former detainees and human rights groups say.
body: Israel Orders Residents of City in Eastern Lebanon to Evacuate

title: Israel’s military warned civilians to leave Baalbek in the Bekaa Valley via three routes. The city had largely been spared Israeli bombardment until this week.
body: Flash Floods in Spain Leave More Than 70 Dead

title: About 1,000 soldiers from emergency response units deployed to the affected areas, and the death toll was expected to rise after one of the worst natural disasters to hit the country in recent years.
body: @nytimes

title: With Limited Options, Zelensky Seeks a Path Forward for Ukraine
body: For weeks, President Volodymyr Zelensky has pushed Western leaders to support his so-called victory plan, but Mr. Zelensky has received only lukewarm rhetorical support.

title: Arrests and Spying Charges Alarm Diplomats and Aid Workers in Yemen
body: The Houthis, an Iran-backed militia that now controls most of Yemen, have recently detained dozens of Yemenis linked to the U.S. Embassy or international organizations, raising fears of a broader crackdown.

title: The New Threat to Brazil’s Forests: Chemicals
body: ﻿Authorities use satellites to track deforestation caused by chain saws or fire. Now criminals are using chemicals to degrade trees — and evade detection.

title: @nytimes
Ukrainian Civilians in Once Safe City Fear Growing Menace of Glide Bombs
body: Cities in eastern and southern Ukraine are increasingly being hit by Russian glide bombs, converted gravity bombs that can be guided to targets, often landing without detection, residents and officials say.

title: Ukraine Braces for Russians to Assault With North Korean Troops
body: The United States warned on Monday that North Korean soldiers were moving toward Russia’s western Kursk region, which Ukraine invaded in August, as Ukrainian forces braced for what they said could be imminent assaults involving the new troops.

title: That’s a Lot of Cheddar: Scammers Steal $390,000 of British Cheese
body: Neal’s Yard, a leading cheese retailer in London, is reeling from the disappearance of 22 metric tons of rare Cheddar worth at least 300,000 pounds, about $390,000, in what appears to be the biggest con to hit their industry in decades.

title: @nytimes
Inside Putin’s Alternate Reality: Warm Embraces and a Veneer of Normalcy
body: For three uninterrupted days this week, President Vladimir V. Putin basked in the attention of other world leaders in the picturesque Russian city of Kazan. He held court at round table discussions during which he pronounced that the West is facing an irreversible process of decline.

title: Russia Raises Interest Rate to 21 Percent, Its Highest in Decades
body: Russia’s central bank raised the cost of borrowing in the country to its highest level in more than two decades on Friday in an effort to slow inflation that is being fueled by record military spending and recruitment.

title: A Pivotal Election for Georgia, Explained
body: Georgia will hold a parliamentary election on Saturday that could determine the country’s geopolitical orientation for years to come as it is pulled between Russia, China and the West.

title: @nytimes
Is Afghanistan’s Most-Wanted Militant Now Its Best Hope for Change?
body: Sirajuddin Haqqani topped the United States’ most-wanted list in Afghanistan, with a $10 million bounty on his head. But since the Taliban’s return to power, Mr. Haqqani has portrayed himself as something else altogether: A voice of relative moderation in a government steeped in religious extremism.

title: Putin Appears to Say That North Korean Troops Are in Russia
body: “If there are images they are a reflection of something,” Putin said in a tongue-in-cheek answer to whether Pyongyang had sent troops to help with Russia’s war in Ukraine.

title: Putin Abandons Caution on North Korea in Pursuit of Victory in Ukraine
body: The invasion of Ukraine has led the Russian leader to jettison cooperation with the West over North Korea’s nuclear arsenal in favor of an ever-deepening military alliance with Pyongyang.

title: @nytimes
U.S. Says North Korean Troops Are in Russia to Aid Fight Against Ukraine
body: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III confirmed on Wednesday that North Korea had sent troops to Russia to join the fight against Ukraine, a major shift in Moscow’s effort to win the war. Mr. Austin called the North’s presence a “very, very serious” escalation that would have ramifications in both Europe and Asia.

title: Draft-Dodging Scandal in Ukraine Forces a Top Official to Quit
body: Ukraine’s prosecutor general has resigned amid a draft-dodging scandal in which hundreds of officials, including prosecutors, are accused of obtaining fake disability certificates that allowed them to avoid military service.

title: Why Is Israel Poised to Attack Iran?
body: The two countries have been fighting a shadow war for years. But direct attacks are bringing direct reprisals, or at least plans for them.

title: @nytimes
U.S. Agrees to Give Ukraine Millions to Build Long-Range Drones
body: The United States has agreed to give Ukraine $800 million in military aid that will go toward manufacturing long-range drones to use against Russian troops, Ukraine’s leader said on Monday.

title: Hamas’s Guerrilla Tactics in North Gaza Make It Hard to Defeat
body: Israel has decimated Hamas’s military wing, along with much of Gaza. But the group’s small-scale, hit-and-run approach poses a threat in the enclave’s north.

title: Putin, Fighting Pariah Status, Welcomes Xi and Other Leaders to Russia
body: Isolated by the West for his war in Ukraine, President Vladimir Putin of Russia scored a diplomatic victory on Tuesday when he welcomed the leaders of China, India and South Africa at the opening of a summit of emerging market countries bidding to rebalance a world order now dominated by the United States.

title: @nytimes
Putin Brings Together Economies He Hopes Will Eclipse the West
body: The Russian leader hopes to use the meeting of the so-called BRICS group, which includes China and India, as a counterweight to the West.

title: Austin, in Ukraine, Announces New Arms Shipment as U.S. Election Looms
body: United States Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III made an unannounced visit to Kyiv on Monday to bolster support for the war effort as Ukrainian forces steadily lose ground to Russian troops and allies stop short of fully endorsing Ukraine’s latest plan to end the conflict.

title: Moldovans, Very Narrowly, Choose to Look Toward Europe, Not Russia
body: A referendum in Moldova intended to put an end to decades of swerving between East and West yielded a microscopic win on Monday for voters who favor amending the Constitution to lock in alignment with Europe rather than Russia.

title: @nytimes
They Came for the Music. They Left With Draft Officers for Ukraine’s Army.
body: Men who attended the Kyiv concert of a popular rock band had their papers checked on the way out. Some were detained. Tickets to subsequent shows suddenly became available.

title: Sinwar’s Death Could Shake but Not Topple Hamas, Experts Say
body: Though the killing of Yahya Sinwar was a powerful blow to Hamas, experts expect the Palestinian militant group to keep fighting.

title: Power Outage Plunges All of Cuba Into Darkness
body: Cuba’s power grid failed and the nation plunged into darkness, less than a day after the country announced emergency measures to save electricity.

title: @nytimes
